channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2024 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2024 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

Asymmetric hydrogenation of ketimines with minimally different alkyl groups

item.title: Anglo-American bias could make generative AI an invisible intellectual cage
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01573-9

Anglo-American bias could make generative AI an invisible intellectual cage
item.dc:title: Anglo-American bias could make generative AI an invisible intellectual cage
item.dc:creator: Queenie Luo
Michael Puett

item.title: Keep an open mind on faster-than-light ‘tachyons’ as the source of quantum entanglement
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01576-6

Keep an open mind on faster-than-light ‘tachyons’ as the source of quantum entanglement
item.dc:title: Keep an open mind on faster-than-light ‘tachyons’ as the source of quantum entanglement
item.dc:creator: Ian Crawford

item.title: Pollen problems: May brings dismay to a hay-fever sufferer in 1874
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01369-x

A book on everyday biology that appeals to non-specialists and specialists alike, and a trek through hay fields causes one Nature reader to experience relentless ‘sneezings’, in the weekly dip into Nature’s archive.
item.dc:title: Pollen problems: May brings dismay to a hay-fever sufferer in 1874

item.title: Adopt stricter regulation to stop ‘critical mineral’ greenwashing
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01574-8

Adopt stricter regulation to stop ‘critical mineral’ greenwashing
item.dc:title: Adopt stricter regulation to stop ‘critical mineral’ greenwashing
item.dc:creator: Andrea Arratia-Solar
David Fleming-Muñoz

item.title: How mathematician Freeman Hrabowski opened doors for Black scientists
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01563-x

Over 30 years, the scholarship programme Hrabowski founded has supported more than 1,500 Black students. He spoke to Nature for our new Changemakers series.
item.dc:title: How mathematician Freeman Hrabowski opened doors for Black scientists
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Thompson

item.title: Don’t leave out joints and bones in exercise studies
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01575-7

Don’t leave out joints and bones in exercise studies
item.dc:title: Don’t leave out joints and bones in exercise studies
item.dc:creator: Francis Berenbaum

item.title: Heed lessons from past studies involving transgender people: first, do no harm
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01521-7

Decades of neuroscientific work have focused on exploring a biological basis for transgender identity — but researchers must take societal factors into account.
item.dc:title: Heed lessons from past studies involving transgender people: first, do no harm
item.dc:creator: Mathilde Kennis
Robin Staicu
Marieke Dewitte
Guy T’Sjoen
Alexander T. Sack
Felix Duecker

item.title: Monsoons are changing in India — here’s how to climate-proof the economy
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01517-3

Global warming is shifting rainfall patterns across South Asia, and each area will be affected differently — local approaches are needed to track and respond to these changes.
item.dc:title: Monsoons are changing in India — here’s how to climate-proof the economy
item.dc:creator: Shravan Prabhu

item.title: Changemakers — Nature’s new series celebrates champions of inclusion in science
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01515-5

All around the world, people are pushing back against racism, gender bias and other forms of discrimination to make a positive difference. Our series will tell their stories and highlight their achievements.
item.dc:title: Changemakers — Nature’s new series celebrates champions of inclusion in science

item.title: Risks of bridge collapses are real and set to rise — here’s why
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01522-6

Hundreds of millions of people cross deficient bridges each day. With damage to these structures likely to intensify because of climate change and ageing, technicians and policymakers must act to make them safer.
item.dc:title: Risks of bridge collapses are real and set to rise — here’s why
item.dc:creator: Jose M. Adam
Nirvan Makoond
Belén Riveiro
Manuel Buitrago

item.title: The AI revolution is coming to robots: how will it change them?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01442-5

The melding of artificial intelligence and robotics could catapult both to new heights.
item.dc:title: The AI revolution is coming to robots: how will it change them?
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Gibney

item.title: I had my white colleagues walk in a Black student’s shoes for a day
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01525-3

Freeman Hrabowski learnt the power of bold actions when he marched for civil rights in his youth. Since then, he has encouraged others to question the status quo — and affirm Black student success in the sciences.
item.dc:title: I had my white colleagues walk in a Black student’s shoes for a day
item.dc:creator: Virginia Gewin

item.title: Autistic people three times more likely to develop Parkinson's-like symptoms
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01572-w

Largest study of its kind also finds increased risk in older adults with a range of intellectual disabilities.
item.dc:title: Autistic people three times more likely to develop Parkinson's-like symptoms
item.dc:creator: Miryam Naddaf

item.title: The immune system can sabotage gene therapies — can scientists rein it in?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01483-w

People treated with gene therapy cannot receive a second dose for fear of a dangerous immune response. Researchers hope to find a way around this.
item.dc:title: The immune system can sabotage gene therapies — can scientists rein it in?
item.dc:creator: Heidi Ledford

item.title: ‘Stop the xenophobia’ — South African researchers sound alarm on eve of election
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01547-x

South Africa’s scientists want the next government to halt declining funding and urge universities to do more to protect international researchers from attacks.
item.dc:title: ‘Stop the xenophobia’ — South African researchers sound alarm on eve of election
item.dc:creator: Sarah Wild

item.title: I study artefacts left in prehistoric caves
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01526-2

Basran Burhan helped to date the oldest piece of figurative art discovered so far.
item.dc:title: I study artefacts left in prehistoric caves
item.dc:creator: James Mitchell Crow

item.title: Researcher parents are paying a high price for conference travel — here’s how to fix it
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01571-x

Three scientist mothers call for a change in how conference childcare costs are reimbursed, drawing on their personal experiences.
item.dc:title: Researcher parents are paying a high price for conference travel — here’s how to fix it
item.dc:creator: Laura Carter
Laura Wolz
Laura J. Pallett

item.title: How artificial intelligence is helping to identify global inequalities
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01534-2

Machine learning tools are helping researchers understand how income is distributed and progress towards reducing inequality.
item.dc:title: How artificial intelligence is helping to identify global inequalities
item.dc:creator: Dom Byrne

item.title: Tackling ‘wicked’ problems calls for engineers with social responsibility
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01519-1

Many technologies are high-risk, and their problems cannot be fixed by policy alone; engineers must embrace social responsibility.
item.dc:title: Tackling ‘wicked’ problems calls for engineers with social responsibility
item.dc:creator: Susan Krumdieck

Author Correction: Bitter taste receptor activation by cholesterol and an intracellular tastant

item.title: Audio long read: How does ChatGPT ‘think’? Psychology and neuroscience crack open AI large language models
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01562-y

To understand the 'brains' of LLMs, researchers are attempting to reverse-engineering artificial intelligence systems.
item.dc:title: Audio long read: How does ChatGPT ‘think’? Psychology and neuroscience crack open AI large language models
item.dc:creator: Matthew Hutson
Benjamin Thompson

item.title: Ozempic keeps wowing: trial data show benefits for kidney disease
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01564-w

Semaglutide, the same compound in obesity drug Wegovy, slashes risk of kidney failure and death for people with diabetes.
item.dc:title: Ozempic keeps wowing: trial data show benefits for kidney disease
item.dc:creator: Rachel Fairbank

item.title: Software tools identify forgotten genes
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01548-w

Find My Understudied Genes and the Unknome database highlight interesting genes that have been neglected by science.
item.dc:title: Software tools identify forgotten genes
item.dc:creator: Matthew Hutson

item.title: Daily briefing: Carrion crows have counting skills seen only in people
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01579-3

Carrion crows can reliably caw a number of times – from one to four – on command. Plus, scientists are racing to make AlphaFold3 more accessible and a new pathway for fentanyl addiction.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Carrion crows have counting skills seen only in people
item.dc:creator: Katrina Krämer

item.title: Neanderthal–human baby-making was recent — and brief
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01452-3

Analysis of dozens of ancient genomes reveals that close encounters between the two species took place in a narrow time window.
item.dc:title: Neanderthal–human baby-making was recent — and brief
item.dc:creator: Michael Eisenstein

item.title: The global economy’s 200-year growth spurt — and what comes next
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01520-8

Can an unlimited supply of innovations and ideas maintain growth without costing the Earth? Yes, a wide-ranging book contends.
item.dc:title: The global economy’s 200-year growth spurt — and what comes next
item.dc:creator: Rutger Hoekstra

item.title: How researchers in remote regions handle the isolation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01523-5

Recruitment challenges and limited resources are among the challenges faced by scientists who live and work off the beaten track.
item.dc:title: How researchers in remote regions handle the isolation
item.dc:creator: Chris Woolston

item.title: What steps to take when funding starts to run out
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01570-y

Although researchers often face uncertainty when grants expire with no replacement in sight, there are creative ways to ease the dry spell.
item.dc:title: What steps to take when funding starts to run out
item.dc:creator: Neil Savage

Nature, Published online: 23 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07579-7

Stereospecific alkenylidene homologation of organoboronates by SNV reaction

item.title: Is that a giant sandwich? No, it’s the biggest protoplanetary disk in the sky
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01401-0

A colossal object called Dracula’s Chivito, referring to an well-stuffed sandwich popular in Uruguay, is the chunkiest planetary nursery known.
item.dc:title: Is that a giant sandwich? No, it’s the biggest protoplanetary disk in the sky

item.title: Two receptors are better than one for AI-designed obesity drugs
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01399-5

Compounds predicted by machine learning attach to two receptors involved in appetite and weight.
item.dc:title: Two receptors are better than one for AI-designed obesity drugs

item.title: These crows have counting skills previously only seen in people
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01482-x

The corvids are the first animals other than humans known to produce a deliberate number of calls on command.
item.dc:title: These crows have counting skills previously only seen in people
item.dc:creator: Mariana Lenharo

item.title: A tiny killer is making an entire region’s sea urchins disintegrate
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01400-1

A single-celled organism is destroying up to 100% of urchins in parts of the Red Sea and the Western Indian Ocean.
item.dc:title: A tiny killer is making an entire region’s sea urchins disintegrate

item.title: Superstar porous materials get salty thanks to computer simulations
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01481-y

Model predicts the structure of previously elusive compounds with practical applications.
item.dc:title: Superstar porous materials get salty thanks to computer simulations
item.dc:creator: Ariana Remmel

item.title: Daily briefing: Why climate change is making flights rougher
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01569-5

Severe turbulence such as those that killed one person on a Singapore Airlines flight, could become more frequent with warming temperatures. Plus, promethium is made into a ‘complex’ for the first time and bizarre bacteria defy textbooks by writing new genes.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Why climate change is making flights rougher
item.dc:creator: Katrina Krämer

item.title: Seed-stashing chickadees overturn ideas about location memory
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01500-y

Certain neurons encode memories of events that occurred in specific physical locations known as place fields. Chickadees show patterns of neuronal activity that are specific to locations of hidden food but independent of place fields.
item.dc:title: Seed-stashing chickadees overturn ideas about location memory
item.dc:creator: Margaret M. Donahue
Laura Lee Colgin

item.title: Who will make AlphaFold3 open source? Scientists race to crack AI model
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01555-x

Researchers are aiming to create fully accessible versions of the latest iteration of DeepMind’s blockbuster protein-structure model.
item.dc:title: Who will make AlphaFold3 open source? Scientists race to crack AI model
item.dc:creator: Ewen Callaway

item.title: Author Correction: A high-density and high-confinement tokamak plasma regime for fusion energy
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07545-3

Author Correction: A high-density and high-confinement tokamak plasma regime for fusion energy
item.dc:title: Author Correction: A high-density and high-confinement tokamak plasma regime for fusion energy

Legionella effector LnaB is a phosphoryl-AMPylase that impairs phosphosignalling

item.title: Laser-powered bullets reveal surprising metal hardness
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01514-6

Micro-ballistics research has shown metals hardening as they are heated, under extreme strain rates.
item.dc:title: Laser-powered bullets reveal surprising metal hardness
item.dc:creator: Dan Fox

item.title: Fentanyl addiction: the brain pathways behind the opioid crisis
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01541-3

How two neural pathways contribute to the deadly opioid’s addictive nature, and why babies are suing the South Korean government.
item.dc:title: Fentanyl addiction: the brain pathways behind the opioid crisis
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Gibney
Nick Petrić Howe

item.title: Greek soldiers prove that ancient armour was combat-worthy
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01402-z

A Mycenean bronze suit did not hamper movement of modern-day warriors performing fighting manoeuvres.
item.dc:title: Greek soldiers prove that ancient armour was combat-worthy

item.title: Mapping model units to visual neurons reveals population code for social behaviour
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07451-8

A deep neural network with ‘knockout training’ is used to model sensorimotor transformations and neural perturbations of male Drosophila melanogaster during visually guided social behaviour and provides predictions and insights into relationships between stimuli, neurons and behaviour.
item.dc:title: Mapping model units to visual neurons reveals population code for social behaviour
item.dc:creator: Benjamin R. Cowley
Adam J. Calhoun
Nivedita Rangarajan
Elise Ireland
Maxwell H. Turner
Jonathan W. Pillow
Mala Murthy

item.title: The solar dynamo begins near the surface
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07315-1

Simple analytic estimates and detailed numerical calculations show that the solar dynamo begins near the surface, rather than at the much-deeper tachocline.
item.dc:title: The solar dynamo begins near the surface
item.dc:creator: Geoffrey M. Vasil
Daniel Lecoanet
Kyle Augustson
Keaton J. Burns
Jeffrey S. Oishi
Benjamin P. Brown
Nicholas Brummell
Keith Julien

item.title: Life-cycle-coupled evolution of mitosis in close relatives of animals
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07430-z

We analyse cell division in ichthyosporeans and find that multinucleated life cycles favour the evolution of closed mitosis, in which the cell constructs a spindle within an intact nucleus.
item.dc:title: Life-cycle-coupled evolution of mitosis in close relatives of animals
item.dc:creator: Hiral Shah
Marine Olivetta
Chandni Bhickta
Paolo Ronchi
Monika Trupinić
Eelco C. Tromer

Gautam Dey

item.title: Natural proteome diversity links aneuploidy tolerance to protein turnover
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07442-9

Proteomic data from natural isolates of Saccharomyces cerevisiae provide insight into how these cells tolerate aneuploidy (an imbalance in the number of chromosomes), and reveal differences between lab-engineered aneuploids and diverse natural yeasts.
item.dc:title: Natural proteome diversity links aneuploidy tolerance to protein turnover

item.title: Covalent targeted radioligands potentiate radionuclide therapy
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07461-6

Radiopharmaceuticals engineered with click chemistry to selectively bind to tumour-specific proteins can be used to successfully target tumour cells, boosting the pharmacokinetics of radionuclide therapy and improving tumour regression.
item.dc:title: Covalent targeted radioligands potentiate radionuclide therapy

item.title: Transcranial volumetric imaging using a conformal ultrasound patch
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07381-5

A conformal ultrasound patch can be used for hands-free volumetric imaging and continuous monitoring of cerebral blood flow
item.dc:title: Transcranial volumetric imaging using a conformal ultrasound patch

item.title: Lense–Thirring precession after a supermassive black hole disrupts a star
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07433-w

The accretion disk from a star tidally disrupted by a supermassive black hole undergoes Lense–Thirring precession with strong, quasi-periodic X-ray flux and temperature modulations.
item.dc:title: Lense–Thirring precession after a supermassive black hole disrupts a star
item.dc:creator: Dheeraj R. Pasham

item.title: Distinct µ-opioid ensembles trigger positive and negative fentanyl reinforcement
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07440-x

Experiments using fentanyl treatment of mice show that µ-opioid receptors mediate positive reinforcement in the ventral tegmental area and negative reinforcement in central amygdala, thereby identifying the circuits that lead to opioid addiction.
item.dc:title: Distinct µ-opioid ensembles trigger positive and negative fentanyl reinforcement
item.dc:creator: Fabrice Chaudun
Laurena Python
Yu Liu
Agnes Hiver
Jennifer Cand
Brigitte L. Kieffer
Emmanuel Valjent
Christian Lüscher

item.title: Adhesive anti-fibrotic interfaces on diverse organs
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07426-9

A study shows that implants with an adhesive implant–tissue interface mitigate the formation of a fibrous capsule when attached to various organs in mice, rats and pigs.
item.dc:title: Adhesive anti-fibrotic interfaces on diverse organs
item.dc:creator: Jingjing Wu
Jue Deng
Georgios Theocharidis
Tiffany L. Sarrafian
Leigh G. Griffiths
Roderick T. Bronson
Aristidis Veves
Jianzhu Chen
Hyunwoo Yuk
Xuanhe Zhao

item.title: Osmosensor-mediated control of Ca<sup>2+</sup> spiking in pollen germination
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07445-6

Screening in Escherichia coli and biochemical experiments show that in Arabidopsis thaliana, OSCA2.1 and OSCA2.2 function as plant sensors of hypo-osmolarity, utilize Ca2+ oscillations as second messengers and have crucial roles in pollen germination.
item.dc:title: Osmosensor-mediated control of Ca<sup>2+</sup> spiking in pollen germination
item.dc:creator: Songyu Pei
Qi Tao

item.title: Porous isoreticular non-metal organic frameworks
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07353-9

The use of computational crystal-structure prediction has enabled the targeted assembly of frameworks of porous organic ammonium halide salts that have many of the qualities of metal–organic frameworks despite containing no metal.
item.dc:title: Porous isoreticular non-metal organic frameworks
item.dc:creator: Megan O’Shaughnessy
Joseph Glover
Roohollah Hafizi
Mounib Barhi
Rob Clowes
Samantha Y. Chong
Stephen P. Argent
Graeme M. Day
Andrew I. Cooper

item.title: Capturing electron-driven chiral dynamics in UV-excited molecules
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07415-y

Time-resolved photoelectron circular dichroism with a temporal resolution of 2.9 fs is used to track the ultrafast electron dynamics following ultraviolet excitation of neutral chiral molecules, which generate chiral currents that exhibit periodic rotation direction reversal.
item.dc:title: Capturing electron-driven chiral dynamics in UV-excited molecules
item.dc:creator: Vincent Wanie
Etienne Bloch
Erik P. Månsson
Lorenzo Colaizzi
Sergey Ryabchuk

item.title: Structural insights into the cross-exon to cross-intron spliceosome switch
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07458-1

Cryo-electron microscopy structures of cross-exon pre-B and B-like complexes contribute new insights into the molecular mechanisms that mediate the switch from a cross-exon to a cross-intron organized spliceosome.
item.dc:title: Structural insights into the cross-exon to cross-intron spliceosome switch
item.dc:creator: Zhenwei Zhang
Vinay Kumar
Olexandr Dybkov
Cindy L. Will
Jiayun Zhong
Sebastian E. J. Ludwig
Henning Urlaub
Berthold Kastner
Holger Stark
Reinhard Lührmann

item.title: A whole-slide foundation model for digital pathology from real-world data
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07441-w

Prov-GigaPath, a whole-slide pathology foundation model pretrained on a large dataset containing around 1.3 billion pathology images, attains state-of-the-art performance in cancer classification and pathomics tasks.
item.dc:title: A whole-slide foundation model for digital pathology from real-world data
item.dc:creator: Hanwen Xu
Naoto Usuyama
Jaspreet Bagga

item.title: Imaging surface structure and premelting of ice Ih with atomic resolution
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07427-8

Atomic-resolution imaging of the surface structure of hexagonal water ice is achieved using cryogenic atomic force microscopy, providing a molecular perspective on the origin and mechanism of of ice premelting.
item.dc:title: Imaging surface structure and premelting of ice Ih with atomic resolution
item.dc:creator: Jiani Hong
Ye Tian
Tiancheng Liang
Xinmeng Liu

Ying Jiang

item.title: Acquisition of epithelial plasticity in human chronic liver disease
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07465-2

Single-cell RNA sequencing and 3D imaging have revealed the cellular changes and structural reorganization that occur during the progression of human chronic liver disease and as the liver attempts to regenerate.
item.dc:title: Acquisition of epithelial plasticity in human chronic liver disease
item.dc:creator: Christopher Gribben
Vasileios Galanakis
Alexander Calderwood

item.title: Observation of a promethium complex in solution
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07267-6

Stable chelation of the 147Pm radionuclide in aqueous solution by the newly synthesized organic diglycolamide ligand is demonstrated and the resulting complex studied, showing accelerated shortening of bonds at the beginning of the lanthanide series.
item.dc:title: Observation of a promethium complex in solution
item.dc:creator: Darren M. Driscoll
Frankie D. White
Subhamay Pramanik

Alexander S. Ivanov

item.title: Metals strengthen with increasing temperature at extreme strain rates
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07420-1

Microballistic impact testing at strain rates greater than 106 s−1 shows that pure metals, including copper, gold and titanium, become stronger with increasing temperature.
item.dc:title: Metals strengthen with increasing temperature at extreme strain rates
item.dc:creator: Ian Dowding
Christopher A. Schuh

item.title: Monolithic three-dimensional tier-by-tier integration via van der Waals lamination
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07406-z

We develop a low-temperature, damage-free process using van der Waals lamination to integrate multiple circuit tiers into a monolithic three-dimensional device, incorporating unique multi-tier functionality and resolving legacy issues with the layering technology.
item.dc:title: Monolithic three-dimensional tier-by-tier integration via van der Waals lamination
item.dc:creator: Donglin Lu
Yang Chen

Likuan Ma

item.title: Electric recycling of Portland cement at scale
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07338-8

Recovered cement paste can be reclinkered if used as a partial substitute for the lime–dolomite flux used in steel recycling, which can reduce waste and carbon emissions.
item.dc:title: Electric recycling of Portland cement at scale
item.dc:creator: Cyrille F. Dunant
Shiju Joseph
Rohit Prajapati
Julian M. Allwood

item.title: Selective haematological cancer eradication with preserved haematopoiesis
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07456-3

An antibody–drug conjugate that targets the pan-haematopoietic marker CD45 combined with transplanted stem cells engineered to be shielded from it can eradicate leukaemic cells while preserving haematopoiesis.
item.dc:title: Selective haematological cancer eradication with preserved haematopoiesis
item.dc:creator: Simon Garaudé

item.title: Kainate receptor channel opening and gating mechanism
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07475-0

Structures of the kainate receptor GluK2 with and without concanavilin A and BPAM344 show how these ligands modulate channel activity and reveal the molecular basis of kainate receptor gating.
item.dc:title: Kainate receptor channel opening and gating mechanism
item.dc:creator: Shanti Pal Gangwar
Maria V. Yelshanskaya
Kirill D. Nadezhdin
Laura Y. Yen
Thomas P. Newton
Muhammed Aktolun
Maria G. Kurnikova
Alexander I. Sobolevsky

item.title: Molecular mechanism of choline and ethanolamine transport in humans
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07444-7

Structural analysis of the human choline and ethanolamine transporters FLVCR1 and FLVCR2 clarifies the mechanisms of transport, the conformational dynamics of these proteins and the disease-associated mutations that interfere with these processes.
item.dc:title: Molecular mechanism of choline and ethanolamine transport in humans
item.dc:creator: Keiken Ri

item.title: Strain-invariant stretchable radio-frequency electronics
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07383-3

Stretchable radio-frequency electronics based on a dielectro-elastic elastomer is demonstrated to be capable of completely maintaining operating frequencies unaffected by strain and shows superior electrical, mechanical and thermal properties compared with conventional stretchable substrate materials.
item.dc:title: Strain-invariant stretchable radio-frequency electronics
item.dc:creator: Sun Hong Kim
Abdul Basir

item.title: Combined cement and steel recycling could cut CO<sub>2</sub> emissions
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01359-z

Cement can be reused by including it as a component of steel recycling. This opens the way to an industrial partnership that improves the use of materials and lowers carbon emissions — but only if waste resources are well managed.
item.dc:title: Combined cement and steel recycling could cut CO<sub>2</sub> emissions
item.dc:creator: Sabbie A. Miller

item.title: Neural pathways for reward and relief promote fentanyl addiction
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01361-5

Neuroscientists find that two distinct neural pathways are responsible for the addictive properties of the opioid fentanyl: one mediates reward, the other promotes the seeking of relief from symptoms of withdrawal.
item.dc:title: Neural pathways for reward and relief promote fentanyl addiction
item.dc:creator: Markus Heilig
Michele Petrella

item.title: Daily briefing: The body odours that make mosquitoes want to bite you
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01545-z

An ambitious field trial in Zambia investigated why mosquitoes seem to find some people more appetizing than others. Plus, anxiety treatments tailored to young brains and the first ‘bilingual’ brain-reading device.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: The body odours that make mosquitoes want to bite you
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Instability could explain the Sun’s curious cycle
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01357-1

A phenomenon that affects the magnetic fields of rotating bodies could be involved in recurring changes in the Sun’s behaviour, which are related to a periodic flipping of its field. The proposal is a fresh take on this strange effect.
item.dc:title: Instability could explain the Sun’s curious cycle
item.dc:creator: Ellen Zweibel

item.title: Guidelines for academics aim to lessen ethical pitfalls in generative-AI use
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01543-1

Researchers warn against normalizing the use of AI without safeguarding against risks.
item.dc:title: Guidelines for academics aim to lessen ethical pitfalls in generative-AI use
item.dc:creator: Liam Drew
